item.name: Abaddon's Reach (Exalted)
entries: This longsword has a hilt which is in the shape of a mask with 6 eye slits, and tentacles coming out of it's back, making up the pommel.
'Act with magic, act within reason, act without mercy.' is inscribed on the blade.
You can use Abaddon's Reach as a spellcasting focus for your spells while attuned to it.
{@bold Dormant.} While Abaddon's Reach is in a dormant state, you gain the following benefits:
• You gain a +1 bonus to attack rolls made with this magic weapon.
• You gain a +1 bonus to spell attack rolls and the saving throw DCs of your spells.
• When you hit with an attack using this weapon, the target takes an extra 1d6 psychic damage.

• You gain an additional volatile 3rd level spell slot. Immediately after you cast a spell using that spell slot, roll a d20. If you roll a 1, roll on the Wild Magic Surge table to create a random magical effect, otherwise the number you need to roll increases by 1, until you trigger a roll on the Wild Magic Surge table, at which point it will reset to 1. A Wild Magic Surge can happen once per turn. You regain this spell slot when you finish a short or long rest.
{@bold Awakened.} When Abaddon's Reach reaches an awakened state, you gain the following benefits:
• The weapon's bonus to attack rolls increases to +2.
• The bonus to spell attack rolls and your spell save DC increases to +2.
• The extra psychic damage dealt by the weapon increases to 2d6.
• The level of your additional spell slot increases to 5th level.
{@bold Exalted.} When Abaddon's Reach reaches an exalted state, you gain the following benefits:
• The weapon's bonus to attack rolls increases to +3.
• The bonus to spell attack rolls and your spell save DC increases to +3.
• The extra psychic damage dealt by the weapon increases to 3d6.
• The level of your additional spell slot increases to 7th level.
{@bold Mastery: Sap.} If you hit a creature with this weapon, that creature has Disadvantage on its next attack roll before the start of your next turn.

item.name: Seeker (Exalted)
entries: This light crossbow is in the shape of a dragon's wing.
'Tyria's last hope rests on the unity of the races. The pooling of their strength. It is the only way.' is inscribed on the grip.
You can use Seeker as a spellcasting focus for your spells while attuned to it.
{@bold Dormant.} While Seeker is in a dormant state, you gain the following benefits:
• You gain a +1 bonus to attack rolls made with this magic weapon.
• You gain a +1 bonus to spell attack rolls and the saving throw DCs of your spells.
• When you hit with an attack using this weapon, the target takes an extra 1d6 piercing damage.

• The first attack roll you make with this weapon each turn scores a critical hit on a 19 or 20, if your target is within 5 feet of an ally of yours. If another feature or trait already gives you an increased critical hit range, increase that range by one instead.
{@bold Awakened.} When Seeker reaches an awakened state, you gain the following benefits:
• The weapon's bonus to attack rolls increases to +2.
• The bonus to spell attack rolls and your spell save DC increases to +2.
• The extra piercing damage dealt by the weapon increases to 2d6.

• The first attack roll you make with this weapon each turn scores a critical hit on a 19 or 20, if you attack with advantage. If another feature or trait already gives you an increased critical hit range, increase that range by one instead.
{@bold Exalted.} When Seeker reaches an exalted state, you gain the following benefits:
• The weapon's bonus to attack rolls increases to +3.
• The bonus to spell attack rolls and your spell save DC increases to +3.
• The extra piercing damage dealt by the weapon increases to 3d6.

• The first attack roll you make with this weapon each turn scores a critical hit on a 19 or 20, while you are concentrating on a spell. If another feature or trait already gives you an increased critical hit range, increase that range by one instead.

{@bold Mastery: Slow.} If you hit a creature with this weapon and deal damage to it, you can reduce its Speed by 10 feet until the start of your next turn. If the creature is hit more than once by weapons that have this property, the Speed reduction doesn't exceed 10 feet.
item.reqAttune: by a member of the Brotherhood of the Dragon

item.name: The Core (Exalted)
entries: This flaming longsword is made of ornamented deldrimor steel, with a heavy core of infernal iron.
'Offer protection to the weak. Give solace and shelter to those who need it. Be ye a salve to the wounded.' is inscribed on the blade.
You can use The Core as a spellcasting focus for your spells while attuned to it.
{@bold Dormant.} While The Core is in a dormant state, you gain the following benefits:
• You gain a +1 bonus to attack rolls made with this magic weapon.
• You gain a +1 bonus to spell attack rolls and the saving throw DCs of your spells.
• When you hit with an attack using this weapon, the target takes an extra 1d6 fire damage.

• On your turn, when you score a critical hit against a creature with The Core or reduce a creature to 0 hit points with it, you gain temporary hit points equal to the challenge rating of the creature or your proficiency bonus, whichever is higher.
{@bold Awakened.} When The Core reaches an awakened state, you gain the following benefits:
• The weapon's bonus to attack rolls increases to +2.
• The bonus to spell attack rolls and your spell save DC increases to +2.
• The extra fire damage dealt by the weapon increases to 2d6.

• On your turn, when you score a critical hit against a creature with The Core or reduce a creature to 0 hit points with it, you can cause flames to erupt, damaging creatures of you choice within 10 feet of you, equal to the challenge rating of the creature or your proficiency bonus, whichever is higher.
{@bold Exalted.} When The Core reaches an exalted state, you gain the following benefits:
• The weapon's bonus to attack rolls increases to +3.
• The bonus to spell attack rolls and your spell save DC increases to +3.
• The extra fire damage dealt by the weapon increases to 3d6.

• Once on your turn, when you score a critical hit against a creature with The Core or reduce a creature to 0 hit points with it, you can make one extra melee weapon attack as part of your attack action.
{@bold Mastery: Sap.} If you hit a creature with this weapon, that creature has Disadvantage on its next attack roll before the start of your next turn.
item.reqAttune: by a member of the Core Warband

item.name: Celestial Slicer (Exalted)
entries: This silver-bladed sickle glimmers softly with moonlight. When looking at the reflection on the blade you can see the night sky.
'Lead through actions, not words!' is inscribed on the silver blade.
You can use the Celestial Slicer as a spellcasting focus for your spells while attuned to it.
You can use the Celestial Slicer as a star map while attuned to it.
{@bold Dormant.} While the Celestial Slicer is in a dormant state, you gain the following benefits:
• You gain a +1 bonus to attack rolls made with this magic weapon.
• You gain a +1 bonus to spell attack rolls and the saving throw DCs of your spells.
• When you hit with an attack using this weapon, the target takes an extra 1d6 radiant damage.

• When you make ranged spell attack roll against a creature, you can target one additional creature and make a second attack roll against it. You can use this feature a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus and regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest.
{@bold Awakened.} When the Celestial Slicer reaches an awakened state, you gain the following benefits:
• The weapon's bonus to attack rolls increases to +2.
• The bonus to spell attack rolls and your spell save DC increases to +2.
• The extra radiant damage dealt by the weapon increases to 2d6.

• If you cast a spell with a spell slot of 1st level or higher and target an ally with the spell, that ally can use their reaction immediately after the spell to make one weapon attack against a creature of your choice that you can see. If the spell targets more than one ally, you choose the ally who can make the attack.
{@bold Exalted.} When the Celestial Slicer reaches an exalted state, you gain the following benefits:
• The weapon's bonus to attack rolls increases to +3.
• The bonus to spell attack rolls and your spell save DC increases to +3.
• The extra radiant damage dealt by the weapon increases to 3d6.
• You can maintain concentration on two spells. When making a Constitution saving throw to maintain concentration, make one for each concentration.

{@bold Mastery: Nick.} When you make the extra attack of the Light property, you can make it as part of the Attack action instead of as a Bonus Action. You can make this extra attack only once per turn.
item.reqAttune: by a member of the Ascalon Vanguard

item.name: Incursion Breaker (Exalted)
entries: This staff is imbued with powerful arcane magic.
'Our gift to the people of Tyria is that they never know just how much danger they've been in.' is inscribed along the shaft of the staff.
You can use Incursion Breaker as a spellcasting focus for your spells while attuned to it.
{@bold Dormant.} While Incursion Breaker is in a dormant state, you gain the following benefits:
• You gain a +1 bonus to attack rolls made with this magic weapon.
• You gain a +1 bonus to spell attack rolls and the saving throw DCs of your spells.
• When you hit with an attack using this weapon, the target takes an extra 1d6 cold damage.
• When you make ranged spell attack roll against a creature, which has been hit by your Tentacle of the Deeps this turn, you can give yourself advantage on that roll.

• When you force a creature to make a saving throw to take half damage, which has been hit by your Tentacle of the Deeps this turn, you can give that target of the spell disadvantage on its first saving throw made against the spell.
{@bold Awakened.} When Incursion Breaker reaches an awakened state, you gain the following benefits:
• The weapon's bonus to attack rolls increases to +2.
• The bonus to spell attack rolls and your spell save DC increases to +2.
• The extra cold damage dealt by the weapon increases to 2d6.
• Once per turn, you can add your proficiency bonus to one damage roll of any spell or class feature, that requires a ranged spell attack roll or which forces a creature to make a saving throw.
{@bold Exalted.} When Incursion Breaker reaches an exalted state, you gain the following benefits:
• The weapon's bonus to attack rolls increases to +3.
• The bonus to spell attack rolls and your spell save DC increases to +3.
• The extra cold damage dealt by the weapon increases to 3d6.

• You can deal maximum damage, instead of rolling for any spell or class feature, that requires a ranged spell attack roll or which forces a creature to make a saving throw. You can use this feature a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus and regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest.

{@bold Mastery: Topple.} If you hit a creature with this weapon, you can force the creature to make a Constitution saving throw (DC 8 plus the ability modifier used to make the attack roll and your Proficiency Bonus). On a failed save, the creature has the Prone condition.
item.reqAttune: by a member of the Wizard's Court

action.name: Cat's Claws
entries: You can use your claws to make unarmed strikes. When you hit with them, the strike deals {@dice 1d6} + your Strength/Dexterity modifier slashing damage, instead of the bludgeoning damage normal for an unarmed strike.

The Charr are aggressive, industrious, and wholly dedicated to becoming the pre-eminent species of Tyria. A savage race of sentient beasts, the Charr will use any means available to destroy their enemies: an ambush is as honorable as a fair fight, as victory is what matters. Though Charr have no concept of mercy, they can be protective of those within their tribe.

trait.name: Pack Tactics
entries: The Grasp of Chaos has advantage on attack rolls against a creature if at least one of the Grasp of Chaos's allies is within 5 feet of the creature and the ally doesn't have the {@condition incapacitated} condition.

action.name: Lunge
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit; reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}12 ({@damage 4d4 + 2}) piercing damage. If the target is a creature, it must succeed on a {@dc 11} Strength saving throw or have the {@condition prone} condition.
Grasps of Chaos guard General Kahyet in the Blacktide Den mission. They are allied at first, then become hostile after a short dialogue.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: The Grasp of Chaos is a 2nd-level spellcaster. Their spellcasting ability is Dexterity (spell save {@dc 12}, +4 to hit with spell attacks). The Grasp of Chaos has the following Warrior (GW) spells prepared:

trait.name: Evasive Teleportation
entries: Whenever it takes damage or is the target of a ranged attack, the Oni can teleport, along with any equipment it is wearing or carrying, to an unoccupied space it can see within 20 feet of itself (no action required). If this effect is triggered by a ranged attack, the Oni teleports just before the attack hits, causing the attack to miss it. This trait is suppressed while the Oni has the {@condition incapacitated} condition.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The Oni makes two Claw attacks.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit; reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}8 ({@damage 3d8 + 4}) slashing damage.

There are some who say that the demonic, savage Oni originate in the Mists, others from someplace even more distant, dark, and cut off from the world of sanity. They are killers from beyond, appearing from nowhere to butcher their victims, for what reason no one knows. Whatever their purpose or origin, the Oni are among the most deadly things on two legs in Cantha.

entries: Whiptail Devourer

Whiptail Devourers are common foes infesting the shattered countryside of Ascalon. They attack primarily by shooting projectiles with their tails. Like all devourers, they are often hidden beneath the surface of the ground, bursting from their hiding place to ambush unsuspecting prey.

trait.name: Assassinate
entries: During its first turn, the whiptail devourer has advantage on attack rolls against any creature that hasn't taken a turn. Any hit the whiptail devourer scores against a {@quickref Surprise|PHB|3|0|surprised} creature is a critical hit.

trait.name: Chameleon Skin
entries: The whiptail devourer has advantage on Dexterity ({@skill Stealth}) checks made to hide.

trait.name: Earth Glide
entries: The whiptail devourer can burrow through nonmagical, unworked earth and stone. While doing so, the whiptail devourer doesn't disturb the material it moves through.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The Whiptail Devourer can make two attacks it can forgo one of these attacks to cast a spell.

action.name: Sting
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 1d6 + 4}) piercing damage.

action.name: Stinger Launch
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 6} to hit, range 90/150 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 1d6 + 4}) piercing damage.

Plague Devourer

Plague Devourers are hardy natural dangers that infest the countryside of Ascalon, both before and after the Searing, although they have become much more common since the Searing. Like all devourers, they are often hidden beneath the surface of the ground, bursting from their hiding place to ambush unsuspecting prey.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: The Plague Devourer is a 5th-level spellcaster. Their spellcasting ability is Wisdom (spell save {@dc 13}, +5 to hit with spell attacks). The Plague Devourer has the following Necromancer (GW) spells prepared:

trait.name: Assassinate
entries: During its first turn, the plague devourer has advantage on attack rolls against any creature that hasn't taken a turn. Any hit the plague devourer scores against a {@quickref Surprise|PHB|3|0|surprised} creature is a critical hit.

trait.name: Chameleon Skin
entries: The plague devourer has advantage on Dexterity ({@skill Stealth}) checks made to hide.

trait.name: Earth Glide
entries: The plague devourer can burrow through nonmagical, unworked earth and stone. While doing so, the plague devourer doesn't disturb the material it moves through.

action.name: Fling Stinger
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 6} to hit, range 60/120 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 1d6 + 4}) piercing damage.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The Hydra (Ascalon) makes as many bite attacks as it has heads.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}9 ({@damage 1d10 + 4}) piercing damage.

trait.name: Multiple Heads (Hydra)
entries: The hydra (ascalon) has three heads. While it has more than one head, the hydra (ascalon) has advantage on saving throws against being {@condition blinded}, {@condition charmed}, {@condition deafened}, {@condition frightened}, {@condition stunned}, and knocked {@condition unconscious}.
Whenever the hydra (ascalon) takes 25 or more damage in a single turn, one of its heads dies. If all its heads die, the hydra (ascalon) dies.

At the end of its turn, it grows two heads for each of its heads that died since its last turn, unless it has taken fire damage since its last turn. The hydra (ascalon) regains 10 hit points for each head regrown in this way.

trait.name: Reactive Heads (Hydra)
entries: For each head the hydra (ascalon) has beyond one, it gets an extra reaction that can be used only for opportunity attacks.

trait.name: Wakeful (Hydra)
entries: While the hydra (ascalon) sleeps, at least one of its heads is awake.

trait.name: Hold Breath (Hydra)
entries: The hydra (ascalon) can hold its breath for 1 hour.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: The Hydra (Ascalon) is a 10th-level spellcaster. Their spellcasting ability is Intelligence (spell save {@dc 16}, +8 to hit with spell attacks). The Hydra (Ascalon) has the following Elementalist (GW) spells prepared:

entries: Hydras are large three-headed lizards that use potent Fire Magic. The Hydras in Ascalon are found in small groups of two to four, throughout the northwest territories of Post-Searing Ascalon. These groups tend to mingle with other indigenous enemies in these areas; for example, with Stone Furies and Boulder Elementals in the Ascalon Foothills, and Charr hunting bands in the Flame Temple Corridor. In the northern region of Dragon's Gullet, Hydra groups flock together in herds, forming lethal mobs when attacked.
Resurrect Gargoyle
Resurrect Gargoyles can be found in groups with Shatter Gargoyles and Flash Gargoyles.

trait.name: False Appearance (Gargoyle)
entries: While the resurrect gargoyle remains motionless, it is indistinguishable from a inanimate statue.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: The Resurrect Gargoyle is a 3rd-level spellcaster. Its spellcasting ability is Wisdom (spell save {@dc 9}, +1 to hit with spell attacks). The Resurrect Gargoyle has the following Monk (GW) spells prepared:

action.name: Fling Lightning
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 1} to hit, range 60/120 ft., one target. {@h}1 ({@damage 1d4 - 1}) lightning damage.

action.name: Resurrect
entries: Resurrect a party member from range, but at the cost of their actions next turn. Choose one friendly dead creature, which has not been dead for more than 1 minute, that you can see within range. That creature returns to life with 25% of their maximum hit points. The creature cannot take actions, bonus actions or reactions until the end of their next turn. This spell can't return to life a creature that has died of old age, nor can it restore any missing body parts.
Shatter Gargoyle
Shatter Gargoyles are found in the company of Flash Gargoyles and sometimes Resurrect Gargoyles.

trait.name: False Appearance (Gargoyle)
entries: While the Shatter Gargoyle remains motionless, it is indistinguishable from a inanimate statue.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: The Shatter Gargoyle is a 7th-level spellcaster. Its spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 14}, +6 to hit with spell attacks). The Shatter Gargoyle has the following Mesmer (GW) spells prepared:

action.name: Fling Chaotic Energy
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 4} to hit, range 60/120 ft., one target. {@h}9 ({@damage 3d4 + 2}) psychic damage.
Flash Gargoyle
Flash Gargoyles can be found on their own or in groups with Shatter Gargoyles and Resurrect Gargoyles.

trait.name: False Appearance (Gargoyle)
entries: While the Flash Gargoyle remains motionless, it is indistinguishable from a inanimate statue.

action.name: Fling Lightning

trait.name: Blood Frenzy
entries: The grawl (ascalon) has advantage on melee attack rolls against any creature that doesn't have all its hit points.

trait.name: Dark Devotion
entries: The grawl (ascalon) has advantage on saving throws against being {@condition charmed} or {@condition frightened}.

trait.name: Rampage
entries: When the grawl (ascalon) reduces a creature to 0 hit points with a melee attack on its turn, the grawl (ascalon) can take a bonus action to move up to half its speed and make another attack.

action.name: Hammer
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}9 ({@damage 1d8 + 5}) bludgeoning damage, or 10 ({@damage 1d10 + 5}) bludgeoning damage if used with both hands.

action.name: Javelin
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 7} to hit, range 90/120 ft., one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d8 + 5}) piercing damage.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: The Grawl (Ascalon) is a 2nd-level spellcaster. Their spellcasting ability is Strength (spell save {@dc 15}, +7 to hit with spell attacks). The Grawl (Ascalon) has the following Warrior (GW) spells prepared:

entries: Grawls are the grunts of the Grawl army. They are often found in patrols with a Grawl Ulodyte.

trait.name: Blood Frenzy
entries: The Grawl Ulodyte has advantage on melee attack rolls against any creature that doesn't have all its hit points.

trait.name: Dark Devotion

trait.name: Rampage
entries: When the Grawl Ulodyte reduces a creature to 0 hit points with a melee attack on its turn, the Grawl Ulodyte can take a bonus action to move up to half its speed and make another attack.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: The Grawl Ulodyte is a 3rd-level spellcaster. Their spellcasting ability is Wisdom (spell save {@dc 15}, +7 to hit with spell attacks). The Grawl Ulodyte has the following Monk (GW) spells prepared:

entries: Grawl Ulodytes are the powerful shamans of the Grawl. In combat, they provide a lot of healing support for Grawl warriors. It may be difficult to defeat groups of Grawl if they have multiple Ulodytes.

action.name: Radiant Scepter
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 7} to hit, range 90/120 ft., one target. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d6 + 5}) radiant damage.
Boulder Elemental
Boulder Elementals are melee fighter elementals that rely on brute force to fight.

action.name: Hurl Rock
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 6} to hit, range 30/90 ft., one target. {@h}4 ({@damage 1d10 + 4}) bludgeoning damage.

reaction.name: Abaddon's Chosen
entries: Once per long rest, when the Margonite is below 50% of their hit point maximum, they can choose to become immune to all damage until the end of their next turn.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The Margonite Executioner can make three hammer attacks, it can forgo one of these attacks to cast a spell.

action.name: Abaddon's Favor
entries: Once per long rest, the Margonite can choose one creature affected by Abaddon's Chosen, all creatures within 15 feet of that creature must succeed on a charisma saving throw or take {@damage 6d6} psychic damage. The target then regains hit points equal to the damage rolled.

action.name: Hammer
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 11} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}20 ({@damage 3d8 + 7}) bludgeoning damage, or 23 ({@damage 3d10 + 7}) bludgeoning damage if used with both hands.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting

entries: Margonite Executioners provide the melee muscle in a Margonite group. While their damage output is weak for a warrior, they can weaken and knock down party members.
White Mantle Knights are the warriors of the White Mantle.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting

action.name: Shortsword
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}12 ({@damage 2d6 + 5}) slashing damage.

action.name: Light Crossbow
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 4} to hit, range 80/320 ft., one target. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d8 + 1}) piercing damage.

Justiciar Hablion was one of the few people who survived the Rise of the White Mantle, and thus one of the few people who could accurately describe the events of that night. He was one of Saul D'Alessio's closest allies up until his disappearance. He would later become a very high-ranking member of the White Mantle.

He first met the Ascalonian refugees at the Gates of Kryta, where they helped him clear the swamp of undead in exchange for asylum in Kryta. He would later encounter them again, giving them the Eye of Janthir to help them select the Chosen - they thought that they would be escorting them to the Temple of the Unseen, but in fact they were to be executed atop the Bloodstone. The Ascalonians learned of this and confronted Hablion, eventually slaying him atop the Bloodstone.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting

action.name: Heavy Crossbow

action.name: Cat's Claws
entries: You can use your claws to make unarmed strikes. When you hit with them, the strike deals {@dice 1d6} + your Strength/Dexterity modifier slashing damage, instead of the bludgeoning damage normal for an unarmed strike.

action.name: Flame Scepter
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 11} to hit, range 60/120 ft., one target. {@h}12 ({@damage 4d8 + 6}) fire damage.

Bonfaaz Burntfur is a powerful Charr chieftain and the leader of the Charr forces assaulting Ascalon. Players first encounter him in The Great Northern Wall mission as he prepares the Charr forces for an invasion of the areas of Ascalon south of the wall. Later on they encounter him in the Nolani Academy mission as he tried to capture the capital city of Rin.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting

footerEntries: *Bonfaaz Burntfur casts these spells on itself before combat.

entries: Bonfaaz Burntfur moves up to its speed without provoking opportunity attacks.

legendary.name: Cantrip

legendary.name: Overcharge Effigy (Costs 3 Actions)
entries: Bonfaaz Burntfur chooses a titan effigy he can see and overcharges it, inspiring all charr within 60-feet of it. Each charr affected has advantage on their next attack roll, has their movement speed doubled for 1 round, and gains one additional action.

trait.name: Dwarven Resilience
entries: They have advantage on saving throws against poison, and they have resistance to poison damage.

One of the oldest races on Tyria, the Dwarves are humanoids that are stocky, short, and are almost always bearded. The dwarves live in the Shiverpeak Mountains - specifically the Northern Shiverpeaks and the Southern Shiverpeaks.

In recent years, the dwarves have been plunged into a civil war between the older Deldrimor dwarves and the recent Stone Summit faction. This war has caused unrest throughout the Shiverpeaks and hold up most travel between Ascalon and the other human nations.

entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d4+4}) piercing damage plus 9 ({@damage 2d8}) necrotic damage.
Dryders are spider-like creatures that can be found throughout Tyria and the Mists.

They are almost exclusively offensive spellcasters, mostly encountered as hex-based necromancers throughout Tyria, and more frequently as elementalists and mesmers in The Mists, where they usually serve Dhuum.
They tend to prefer very cold or icy places, such as the Shiverpeaks mountains, or on the contrary extremely hot places, such as the Ring of Fire Islands.
They also seem to feed on souls as they are frequently seen next to dead bodies or souls, and their skills (Soul Leech, Soul Torture) further references that.
According to Nicholas the Traveler, Frostfire Dryders have poisonous fangs, however none of the Dryders in the game can actually inflict poison.

trait.name: Ice Walk
entries: The ice elemental can move across and climb icy surfaces without needing to make an ability check. Additionally, difficult terrain composed of ice or snow doesn't cost it extra movement.

trait.name: Splinter
entries: A creature that hits the ice elemental with a melee weapon attack that deals bludgeoning damage while within 5 feet of the elemental takes 10 ({@damage 3d6}) piercing damage as shards of ice fly out from the elemental's body.

entries: The Ice Golem makes two attacks: two with its Ice Claw, it can forgo one of these attacks to cast a spell.

action.name: Ice Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}17 ({@damage 3d8 + 4}) slashing damage.

action.name: Encase in Ice
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 10 ft., one creature. {@h}14 ({@damage 4d6}) cold damage, and the target must make a {@dc 13} Constitution saving throw. On a failure, ice begins to form around the creature, and it is {@condition restrained}. The {@condition restrained} creature must repeat the saving throw at the end of its next turn, becoming {@condition petrified} in ice on a failure or ending the effect on a success. The petrification lasts until the creature spends at least 1 hour in a warm environment. Alternatively, a creature can be freed of the {@condition restrained} or {@condition petrified} conditions if it takes at least 10 fire damage.

An old folk legend states the only reason Dolyaks were domesticated instead of minotaurs is because minotaurs would rather be beaten to death than obey a command. Dolyaks, simply put, were less stubborn. Minotaurs are one of the oldest species in Tyria and are very much prized by the Norn for their warm, furry coats. They were once extremely populous throughout the Shiverpeaks but now reside solely in the northern regions, where they have sheltered valleys and caves to make their homes.

The wise king of the Deldrimor dwarves, King Jalis Ironhammer rules his people from the peaks of the Shiverpeak mountains. He is a smart, strong, patient man who makes decisions based solely on how they will affect the well-being of all the dwarves in Deldrimor. He lives to serve his people, and they love and respect him for it.

There are those, however, who wish to see the good king taken out of power. Namely, the Stone Summit, a group of xenophobic dwarves who had broken their ties with Deldrimor and are trying to take control of the dwarven nation. Over the past several years, the Summit have been growing their power, and a civil war is brewing.

King Jalis Ironhammer does not want to fight other dwarves, but he will do what he must to keep his people safe. Along with his loyal brother, Brechnar Ironhammer, the king has rallied his forces, and they stand ready to defend their home. The question on the king's mind though is this: Can he win?

Nicholas Sandford (born 1035 AE) is an Ascalonian traveler, a craftsman and a writer.

Nicholas met his dolyak friend, Professor Yakkington, during a snowstorm in the Northern Shiverpeaks. The two managed to survive by huddling together for warmth and they have been together ever since.

Due to the Searing, Nicholas lost his parents, friends and beloved Mary Malone. After having mourned in seclusion for years, his hair grown white, he started to travel the world and dropped his last name in favor of the moniker "the Traveler".
He has made many friends, including Gwen and Durmand, and is often seen collecting items to aid them (especially Durmand or Zinn) in some form, or catering to Yakkington's whims.

A true craftsman, Nicholas is able to make various tools and even small sculptures out of various items he finds. Once he helped Vael by making a disguise out of Quetzal Crests so Vael could spy on the Tengu of Cantha.
In exchange, he has gathered up a hefty supply of exotic and unique items to put in his Gifts of the Traveler, which he trades with adventurers in exchange for the items he needs.
Nicholas is very interested in local folklore, in fauna and flora. As a writer he has written a novel entitled "There with Yakkington: A Traveler's Tale.".

He also claims to be a gourmet chef, thanks to the various different foods he has tasted throughout his travels, which his friendship with Imperial Chef Yileng may suggest to be true, and a medic, as he is often seen trying to come up with some remedy to counteract various poisons (notably those inflicted by Dryders or Rot Wallows).

Professor Yakkington (born in 1057 AE) is the companion of Nicholas Sandford the Traveler. He was found by Nicholas during a blizzard in Traveler's Vale, having been abandoned by his mother like most young Dolyaks perceived to be weak. After using each other for warmth in the blizzard, Yakkington has joined Nicholas in his travels across Tyria.

In their travels, Yakkington is the fighter of the pair, holding back the wildlife for Nick. He also has a good sense of smell which comes in handy when trying to find their path again should they get lost.

Since his travels, Yakkington has become pampered by Nicholas, and often becomes stubborn. He enjoys having daily sweets and eating Red Iris Flowers, but has a strong fear of snakes and darkness. Because of his fears, Nick often puts Enchanted Lodestones to act as lights at night when Yakkington sleeps. According to Nick, he is 6'8", weighs about a ton, and his lucky number is 5.

bonus.name: Ursan Force {@recharge 4}
entries: For 3 rounds, your speed is increased by 10 feet, and you cannot be knocked {@condition prone}.

bonus.name: Ursan Roar {@recharge}
entries: Choose any number of friendly creatures that can hear you and are within 150-feet of you. For 1 round, the next time a target hits with a weapon attack, they deal an additional {@damage 1d6} damage.

Additionally, choose any number of hostile creatures that can hear you and are within 150-feet of you. Each target must make a Wisdom saving throw. On a failed save, a target is {@condition weakness|GuildWars|weakened} for 1 round.

As the Spirit of ferocity and confidence and the natural embodiment of all bears, Bear is the most revered of all the Spirits of the Wild and is said to be an icon of strength, insight, and wisdom. According to ancient myths, she bestowed the norn with the totem ability to Become the Bear. The norn view Bear as both a Mother who protects her cubs and a Sister who helps people find their inner strength. She is said to give norn the power to face all odds, but some norn are aware that she can also strike with surprising speed. Because of the ursine appearance of the kodan, some norn believe that the kodan are blessed by Bear. Some followers of Bear claim that she has appeared in their dreams to give them guidance.

The Prize Moa Bird belonged to Pitney, before it disappeared deep into The Catacombs.

action.name: Impress
entries: Madam Featherbutt puts on a show for a spectral penal of judges. She does a performance check, and depending on the result, gains one of the following benefits:
1-10: Not impressed! — Madam Featherbutt has disadvantage on all saving throws until the end of her turn.
11-20: Impressive! — Madam Featherbutt has advantage on all saving throws until the end of her turn.
21+: Truly Magnanimous! — Madam Featherbutt has done such a good job impressing the judges that she gains plot armor and is immune to all damage and conditions until the DM decides otherwise.

reaction.name: "Not my prized Moa bird!"
entries: Madam Featherbutt can choose not to take damage from any source.

trait.name: Flyby
entries: Madam Featherbutt doesn't provoke opportunity attacks when she flies out of an enemy's reach.

legendary.name: Flutter
entries: Madam Featherbutt moves up to her speed without provoking opportunity attacks.

trait.name: Cunning Action
entries: On each of his turns, Rornark Stonesledge can use a bonus action to take the Dash, Disengage, or Hide action.

trait.name: Sneak Attack
entries: Once per turn, Rornark Stonesledge can deal an extra 7 ({@dice 2d6}) damage when he hits a target with a weapon attack and has advantage on the attack roll, or when the target is within 5 feet of an ally of Rornark Stonesledge that isn't {@condition incapacitated} and Rornark Stonesledge doesn't have disadvantage on the attack roll.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: Rornark Stonesledge makes two shortsword attacks.

action.name: Shortsword
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}12 ({@damage 2d6 + 5}) piercing damage, or 19 ({@damage 4d6 + 5}) piercing damage while enlarged.

action.name: Hand Crossbow
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 8} to hit, range 30/120 ft., one target. {@h}12 ({@damage 2d6 + 5}) piercing damage.

Rornak Stonesledge is a Deldrimor spy who is frequently captured by enemy forces. He can be encountered during three missions in the Shiverpeaks, and in each case when freed by the player he initiates the mission's bonus objective.

He can first be encountered in Borlis Pass after having been caught by the Stone Summit forces in Maladar's Fort, where he learned of a plan to unleash an Ice Drake on Grooble's Gulch. When he is freed, he beseeches the player character to find and kill the Ice Drake. He is soon captured again on the path to the Frost Gate while trying to steal the Stone Summit's Secret Siege Weapon Plans. He is left in a dryder cave, and when rescued he enlists the player character's help to steal the plans, and repairs a Stone Summit ballista to blast open the gate protecting them.

He can be found a third time, much later, in the Ice Caves of Sorrow, this time a prisoner of the Mursaat after he was caught scouting for an alternative way into the White Mantle prison camp. When he is freed once more, he asks that Hamdor Grandaxe's rescue party be told where he is.

reaction.name: Invoke the Great Dwarf
entries: Once per day, if Rornark Stonesledge fails a saving throw, he can choose to succeed instead.

As the Spirit of knowledge and foresight and the natural embodiment of ravens, Raven is said to be a trickster who is fond of riddles and wordplay and likes to test the wits of his followers and anyone else who wishes to uncover his secrets. He calls his followers fledglings, inspires artists, and also favors acts of kindness towards ravens who are viewed as his flock. In some cases Raven is believed to personally come to take the life of a norn who was about to die and guide the soul to the Mists.

The norn believe that Raven sees and knows all, and requires nothing but the petitioner's promise to always seek wisdom to grant them his blessing of swiftness. He only views someone unworthy in his eyes if the person does not learn from their mistakes, and he rewards the clever, the sincere, and those who seek out new experiences such as traveling the world.Although Raven represents the facets of mind that grant beings the vision to see and the wisdom to understand, his teachings also contain a darker side.

trait.name: Keen Senses
entries: The corvid transformation has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on sight, hearing or smell.

action.name: Raven Talons
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}10 ({@damage 2d4 + 5}) slashing damage. On hit, the target must succeed on a Constitution saving throw or become {@condition crippled|GuildWars} and start {@condition bleeding|GuildWars}, taking {@damage 1d4} damage, for 1 minute.
At the end of each of its turns, the target can make a Constitution saving throw for each condition affecting it. On a success, that condition ends.

As the natural embodiment of all owls, Owl was revered as one of the Spirits of the Wild among the norn. Although she was a gentle Spirit who embodied home and hearth, she was also a silent and clever predator with ambush-like swiftness and precision. Helping the sick and wounded pleased her. Owl put her family's needs and safety above all else, often teaching others that the purpose of the hunt was not just to kill but also to provide and protect. Tales about Owl depict her offering her wisdom to both norn and her fellow Spirits of the Wild.

As the natural embodiment of all owls, Owl was revered as one of the Spirits of the Wild among the norn. Although she was a gentle Spirit who embodied home and hearth, she was also a silent and clever predator with ambush-like swiftness and precision. Helping the sick and wounded pleased her. Owl put her family's needs and safety above all else, often teaching others that the purpose of the hunt was not just to kill but also to provide and protect. Tales about Owl depict her offering her wisdom to both norn and her fellow Spirits of the Wild.

As the Spirit of teamwork, friendship, family, and the natural embodiment of all wolves, Wolf is said to be dedicated to brotherhood as he imparts the virtues of loyalty, ferocity, and strength in numbers. He is revered as a masculine spirit, and the norn call him their brother, son, father, and uncle when they ask for his blessing. According to old tales, Owl taught Wolf how his hunting would be for naught if his family dined alone, making Wolf heed Owl's wisdom as he returned to his cubs. Although in some cases Raven was believed to personally come to take the life of a norn who was about to die and guide the soul to the Mists, Wolf was also known to do the same to people who walked in his footsteps.

entries: The volfen transformation has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on hearing or smell.

trait.name: Pack Tactics
entries: The volfen transformation has advantage on an attack roll against a creature if at least one of the volfen transformation's allies is within 5 feet of the creature and the ally isn't {@condition incapacitated}.

At the end of each of its turns, a target can make a Constitution saving throw. On a success, the condition ends.

bonus.name: Volfen Agility {@recharge 4}
entries: For 1 round, increase the range in which your recharge abilities recharge by 1.

bonus.name: Volfen Pounce {@recharge 5}
entries: For 1 round, your speed is increased by 20% and the next time you hit with an attack, it deals an additional {@damage 1d12} damage in a 5-foot radius around the attack target, ignoring you.

bonus.name: Volfen Bloodlust {@recharge}

entries: They have advantage on saving throws against poison, and they have resistance to poison damage.

trait.name: Legendary Resistance (1/Day)
entries: If the stone summit sage boss fails a saving throw, it can choose to succeed instead.
Saris Headstaver is a Stone Summit boss that appears in the Borlis Pass mission and Traveler's Vale.

reaction.name: Invoke the Great Destroyer
entries: Once per day the stone summit dwarf can cast {@spell Hellish Rebuke} at 3rd level using this ability.

action.name: Warhammer
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}16 ({@damage 3d8 + 3}) bludgeoning damage, or 19 ({@damage 3d10 + 3}) bludgeoning damage if used with both hands.

action.name: Shortbow
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 6} to hit, range 80/320 ft., one target. {@h}9 ({@damage 2d6 + 2}) piercing damage.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: The Stone Summit Conjurer is a 13th-level spellcaster. Their spellcasting ability is Intelligence (spell save {@dc 17}, +9 to hit with spell attacks). The Stone Summit Conjurer has the following Elementalist (GW) spells prepared:
footerEntries: *The Stone Summit Conjurer casts these spells on itself before combat.

legendary.name: Move
entries: The Stone Summit Conjurer moves up to its speed without provoking opportunity attacks.

legendary.name: Cast a Spell (Costs 2 Actions)
entries: The Stone Summit Conjurer uses Spellcasting.

monster.name: Wraith
languages: the languages it knew in life

trait.name: Incorporeal Movement
entries: The wraith can move through other creatures and objects as if they were {@quickref difficult terrain||3}. It takes 5 ({@damage 1d10}) force damage if it ends its turn inside an object.

trait.name: Sunlight Sensitivity
entries: While in sunlight, the wraith has disadvantage on attack rolls, as well as on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on sight.

action.name: Life Drain
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature. {@h}21 ({@damage 4d8 + 3}) necrotic damage. The target must succeed on a {@dc 15} Constitution saving throw or its hit point maximum is reduced by an amount equal to the damage taken. This reduction lasts until the target finishes a long rest. The target dies if this effect reduces its hit point maximum to 0.

action.name: Create Specter
entries: The wraith targets a humanoid within 10 feet of it that has been dead for no longer than 1 minute and died violently. The target's spirit rises as a {@creature specter} in the space of its corpse or in the nearest unoccupied space. The {@creature specter} is under the wraith's control. The wraith can have no more than seven specters under its control at one time.
Wraiths are undead mesmers found in Kryta.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: The Wraith is an 8th-level spellcaster. Their spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 15}, +7 to hit with spell attacks). The Wraith has the following Mesmer (GW) spells prepared:

languages: the languages it knew in life

trait.name: Incorporeal Movement
entries: The Smoke Phantom can move through other creatures and objects as if they were {@quickref difficult terrain||3}. It takes 5 ({@damage 1d10}) force damage if it ends its turn inside an object.

action.name: Static Shock
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature. {@h}12 ({@damage 2d8 + 3}) lightning damage. The target must succeed on a {@dc 15} Constitution saving throw or be {@condition stunned} until the end of their next turn.
Smoke Phantoms are the Elementalist of the Undead army, they can be annoying for low armor groups due to their Chain Lightning spell.

**The Smoke Phantom casts this spell on an ally before combat.

trait.name: False Appearance (Treant)
entries: While the Oakheart (Kryta) remains motionless, it appears as a great oak.

trait.name: Siege Monster
entries: The Oakheart (Kryta) deals double damage to objects and structures.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The Oakheart (Kryta) makes two slam or Rock attacks.

action.name: Slam
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}16 ({@damage 3d6 + 5}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Rock
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 8} to hit, range 60/180 ft., one target. {@h}28 ({@damage 4d10 + 5}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Animate Trees (1/Day)
entries: The Oakheart (Kryta) magically animates one or two trees it can see within 60 feet of him. These trees have the same statistics as the Oakheart (Kryta), except they have Intelligence and Charisma scores of 1, they can't speak, and they have only the Rock action option. An animated tree acts as an ally of the Oakheart (Kryta). The tree remains animate for 1 day or until it dies; until the Oakheart (Kryta) dies or is more than 120 feet from the tree; or until the Oakheart (Kryta) takes a bonus action to turn them back into an inanimate tree. The tree then takes root if possible.
Oakhearts are sturdy plants found in Kryta.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting

footerEntries: *The Oakheart (Kryta) casts these spells on itself before combat.

trait.name: Plant Camouflage
entries: The Large Spined Aloe has advantage on Dexterity ({@skill Stealth}) checks it makes in any terrain with ample obscuring plant life.

trait.name: Regeneration
entries: The Large Spined Aloe regains 3 hit points at the start of its turn. If it takes cold, fire, or necrotic damage, this trait doesn't function at the start of The Large Spined Aloe's next turn. The Large Spined Aloe dies only if it starts its turn with 0 hit points and doesn't regenerate.

action.name: Claws
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d6 + 2}) slashing damage.

action.name: Throw Rock
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 4} to hit, range 30/120 ft., one target. {@h}4 ({@damage 1d4 + 2}) bludgeoning damage.
Large Spined Aloe are plants that are usually buried near Oakhearts. They are always buried and popup when approached.

trait.name: Evasion
entries: If the reed stalker is subjected to an effect that allows it to make a Dexterity saving throw to take only half damage, the reed stalker instead takes no damage if it succeeds on the saving throw, and only half damage if it fails.

trait.name: Swamp Camouflage
entries: The reed stalker has advantage on Dexterity ({@skill Stealth}) checks made to hide in swampy terrain.

trait.name: False Appearance (Reed Stalker)
entries: While the reed stalker remains motionless, it is indistinguishable from a normal reed.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting

footerEntries: **The Reed Stalker casts these spells on an ally before combat.

bonus.name: Hide
entries: The reed stalker takes the hide action.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}11 ({@damage 2d6 + 4}) slashing damage, plus 3 ({@damage 1d6}) psychic damage.

action.name: Fling
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 6} to hit, range 60/120 ft., one target. {@h}14 ({@damage 3d6 + 4}) piercing damage, plus 3 ({@damage 1d6}) psychic damage.

Reed Stalkers are violent plant creatures that inhabit the swamps and marshes of Kryta. They attack in numbers, but the real danger comes from their mesmer skills, which make them dangerous to attack, and equally dangerous to ignore.

monster.name: Hell Hound
languages: understands Infernal but can't speak it

trait.name: Keen Hearing and Smell
entries: The hound has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on hearing or smell.

trait.name: Pack Tactics
entries: The hound has advantage on an attack roll against a creature if at least one of the hound's allies is within 5 feet of the creature and the ally isn't {@condition incapacitated}.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 1d8 + 3}) piercing damage plus 7 ({@damage 2d6}) necrotic damage.

action.name: Necrotic Breath {@recharge 5}
entries: The hound exhales necrotic energy in a 15-foot cone. Each creature in that area must make a {@dc 12} Dexterity saving throw, taking 21 ({@damage 6d6}) necrotic damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

Hellhounds are undead creatures that are usually accompanied by a handler, like an Executioner or a Hellhound Keeper. Though they may appear like standard undead, they are actually constructs, much like a necromancer's minion.

trait.name: Charge
entries: If the minotaur moves at least 10 feet straight toward a target and then hits it with a gore attack on the same turn, the target takes an extra 4 ({@damage 1d8}) piercing damage. If the target is a creature, it must succeed on a {@dc 14} Strength saving throw or be pushed up to 10 feet away and knocked {@condition prone}.

Dagnar Stonepate is the cousin of Jalis Ironhammer and the founder and original leader of the xenophobic Stone Summit. With the Stone Summit, he has begun a civil war in the Shiverpeak Mountains with the Deldrimor Dwarves, enslaved many other races including Dolyaks, snow beasts, and humans, and aspires to rule all of Tyria.

entries: {@atk ms} {@hit 12} to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature. {@h}10 ({@damage 3d6}) cold damage. The target must succeed on a {@dc 18} Constitution saving throw or be {@condition paralyzed} for 1 minute. The target can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

legendary.name: Cantrip
entries: The lich casts a cantrip.

legendary.name: Paralyzing Touch (Costs 2 Actions)
entries: The lich uses its Paralyzing Touch.

legendary.name: Frightening Gaze (Costs 2 Actions)
entries: The lich fixes its gaze on one creature it can see within 10 feet of it. The target must succeed on a {@dc 18} Wisdom saving throw against this magic or become {@condition frightened} for 1 minute. The {@condition frightened} target can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success. If a target's saving throw is successful or the effect ends for it, the target is immune to the lich's gaze for the next 24 hours.

legendary.name: Disrupt Life (Costs 3 Actions)
entries: Each non-undead creature within 20 feet of the lich must make a {@dc 18} Constitution saving throw against this magic, taking 21 ({@damage 6d6}) necrotic damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

Vizier Khilbron is the last known survivor of Orr following the Cataclysm, and the ex-advisor to King Reza of Orr. He is responsible for the Cataclysm after reading a dark incantation from the Lost Scrolls, defeating the Charr army at the gates of Arah, but, in turn, destroying the entire kingdom.

Evennia of the Shining Blade makes a deal with him that, in return for the Scepter of Orr, he will lend his aid to the conflict between them and the White Mantle and the Unseen Ones. In 1072 AE, late into the Season of the Scion, he tricks the players into opening the Door of Komalie at the Ring of Fire Island Chain, setting free the Titans which he then controls using the scepter, and reveals his second, new identity. The Cataclysm did not spare him, but instead transformed him into the Undead Lich.
While in his Undead Lich form, he is defeated by the players while standing atop the bloodstone in front of the Door of Komalie.

The Vizier's decision to read from the Lost Scrolls to defeat the invading Charr has been seen as noble by some and deranged by others. Scholars debate whether a Charr victory in Orr would have been preferable to the nation's complete destruction, or that, under the circumstances, the Vizier could have made no other decision, and that the outcome of the spell could not have been foreseen.

It is revealed in the Realm of Torment that Terick, an Orrian citizen (who was in reality Razakel, a demonic agent of Abaddon) had convinced Khilbron into using the dark magic that caused the Cataclysm. The specter of Jutu later reveals that Khilbron was not simply coerced into using the magic but had also been converted to the worship of Abaddon prior to the Cataclysm.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: Verata the Necromancer is a 12th-level spellcaster. His spellcasting ability is Intelligence (spell save {@dc 16}, +8 to hit with spell attacks). Verata the Necromancer has the following Necromancer (GW) spells prepared:
footerEntries: *Verata the Necromancer casts these spells on himself before combat.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The necromancer makes three Arcane Burst attacks.

action.name: Arcane Burst
entries: {@atk ms,rs} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 5 ft. or range 120 ft., one target. {@h}25 ({@damage 4d10 + 3}) necrotic damage.

bonus.name: Summon Undead (1/Day)
entries: The necromancer magically summons five {@creature skeleton||skeletons} or {@creature zombie||zombies}. The summoned creatures appear in unoccupied spaces within 60 feet of the necromancer, whom they obey. They take their turns immediately after the necromancer. Each lasts for 1 hour, until it or the necromancer dies, or until the necromancer dismisses it as a bonus action.

reaction.name: Grim Harvest (1/Turn)
entries: When the necromancer kills a creature with necrotic damage, the necromancer regains 9 ({@damage 2d8}) hit points.

Verata is the first Necromancer Profession quest giver in pre-Searing Ascalon. After the Searing, he continued his research on undead minions, but his eager desire for knowledge caused him to use forbidden practices to increase the speed of his research. Because of this, he became an outcast of "the Order" and formed his own guild.

trait.name: Legendary Resistance (2/Day)
entries: If the verata the necromancer fails a saving throw, he can choose to succeed instead.

legendary.name: Move
entries: Verata the Necromancer moves up to his speed without provoking opportunity attacks.

legendary.name: Attack
entries: Verata the Necromancer attacks using one of his attacks.

legendary.name: Cast a Spell (Costs 2 Actions)
entries: Verata the Necromancer uses Spellcasting.
Galrath is a warrior seeking to learn arcane magic at the Wizard's Tower in Kryta; stopping him is the objective of the Villainy of Galrath.

monster.name: Wraith Mesmer Boss
languages: the languages it knew in life

trait.name: Incorporeal Movement
entries: The wraith can move through other creatures and objects as if they were {@quickref difficult terrain||3}. It takes 5 ({@damage 1d10}) force damage if it ends its turn inside an object.

trait.name: Sunlight Sensitivity
entries: While in sunlight, the wraith has disadvantage on attack rolls, as well as on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on sight.

trait.name: Legendary Resistance (2/Day)
entries: If the wraith mesmer boss fails a saving throw, it can choose to succeed instead.

action.name: Life Drain
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature. {@h}31 ({@damage 6d8 + 4}) necrotic damage. The target must succeed on a {@dc 16} Constitution saving throw or its hit point maximum is reduced by an amount equal to the damage taken. This reduction lasts until the target finishes a long rest. The target dies if this effect reduces its hit point maximum to 0.

action.name: Create Specter
entries: The wraith targets a humanoid within 10 feet of it that has been dead for no longer than 1 minute and died violently. The target's spirit rises as a {@creature specter} in the space of its corpse or in the nearest unoccupied space. The {@creature specter} is under the wraith's control. The wraith can have no more than seven specters under its control at one time.
Gaiza Deadeye is a Wraith boss found only during Riverside Province.
Zaim Grimeclaw is an undead boss in the Sanctum Cay mission.

Magi Malaquire is an eccentric old wizard found in Lion's Arch. He instructs Prophecies characters how to use the Signet of Capture through various quests. Afterwards, players may also buy Signets of Capture and any skills previously unlocked from him.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}19 ({@damage 3d10 + 3}) piercing damage.

items.name: Shard Breath.
items.entry: The Bone Dragon exhales a 15-foot cone of bone shards. Each creature in that area must make a {@dc 15} Dexterity saving throw, taking 26 ({@damage 6d8}) piercing damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

items.name: Noxious Breath.
items.entry: The Bone Dragon exhales a 15-foot cone of gas. Each creature in the area must succeed on a {@dc 15} Constitution saving throw or become {@condition poisoned} for 1 minute. A creature {@condition poisoned} in this way can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the {@condition poisoned} condition on itself on a success.

entries: Bone Dragons are found throughout the Kryta region in the Prophecies campaign. Bone Dragons as we see them are only half of their original bodies, the lower half having torn off due to the pure strength of the Bone Dragons' forearms when they were risen from their graves.

Bearn the Implacable is a White Mantle boss that appears in Riverside Province.
Brogan the Punisher is a White Mantle boss located in Twin Serpent Lakes.

Erulai the Inimical can be found on the Bloodstone during the mini-mission part of the All for One and One for Justice quest. He was once a friend of Olias, before Olias realized the truth of things and left.
Kenric the Believer is a White Mantle boss that is part of the expedition seeking to gain access to the Henge of Denravi ahead of the Shining Blade.
Oswald the Amiable is a White Mantle boss that may appear in Bloodstone Fen.
